title: Champions / Europa League Match Week 2
body_text:
Discussion about the various European games taking place this week can go here.
By Lyndon Lloyd 05/10/2023
Share:
Discussion about the various European games taking place this week can go here.
Note: the following content is not moderated or vetted by the site owners at the time of submission. Comments are the responsibility of the poster. Disclaimer ()
Dave Abrahams
1 Posted 03/10/2023 at 20:59:51

Was it just some kind of sick dream, or was Carlo once manager of Everton FC?

3 Posted 03/10/2023 at 21:17:32

Napoli are heating it up here. Kvartawhatever is cookin'.
We should have gone for Rudi Garcoa when we got Frank. It might have ended as a trainwreck but that would have been better than the damp squib we got.

6 Posted 03/10/2023 at 22:07:38
6 Posted 03/10/2023 at 22:07:38
Seems a few posts on the Napoli v Real Madrid game, but did anyone watch Man Utd v Galatasaray?
Pickford can take a bit of stick from Everton fans but, believe me, I'd rather him than that clown in goal for Man Utd. A terrible pass out of his own area straight to a Galatasaray player, who was then brought down by Casemiro for a penalty.
Casemiro red-carded for two yellows. Penalty was put wide, but the player who missed scored a few minutes later with a delicate chip over Onana, who went down far too early.
Onana seems to have a mistake in him every game. £44M for him. Inter Milan must be laughing all the way to the bank. Man Utd now bottom on zero points.
Dale Self
7 Posted 03/10/2023 at 22:32:17
7 Posted 03/10/2023 at 22:32:17
Dave, it definitely deflected off a Napoli defender. I think the keeper got a hand to it but it was so strong it went in off the underside of the bar.
I only saw the one replay so maybe there was a bounce off the keeper. Decent game but that Napoli back line let them down aside from the opening goal.
Paul Morrison

Danny Oâ€™Neill
12 Posted 04/10/2023 at 19:27:05
12 Posted 04/10/2023 at 19:27:05
It get's worse. If it was bad enough listening to the latest episode of replay-gate, now they're on the one show being touted as the greenest club in English football, growing flowers and Maura making apple crumble with apples grown in the allotment at their Kirkby (yes Kirkby) training ground. That said, ours is in Halewood.
I feel sick. I can see a long build up to the Derby but lets get Bournemouth out of the way first before I start all of my superstitious rituals before we make the journey to our former home.
Barry Hesketh
13 Posted 04/10/2023 at 19:29:24
13 Posted 04/10/2023 at 19:29:24
Think it was 1969 when Newcastle lifted the Fairs Cup Paul.
Everton finished 5th in 1968 but lost the European place due to that nonsensical one city one club rule and also missed out due to losing the FA Cup final to WBA. Newcastle ended that campaign in tenth place to qualify for the Fairs Cup.

Joe Harvey was the manager of Newcastle from 1962 until Gordon Lee took the job in 1975. Barraclough I seem to remember as a player, not sure he managed them but if he did it would have been much later.

29 Posted 04/10/2023 at 19:48:49
29 Posted 04/10/2023 at 19:48:49
Major trophy! Friendly games were regularly held between teams from cities holding trade fairs and it was from these games that the competition evolved. The competition was initially only open to teams from cities that hosted trade fairs and where these teams finished in their national league had no relevance.
Rob Halligan

30 Posted 04/10/2023 at 19:56:36
The last major trophy of note they won, was the FA Cup in 1955. 68 years ago.
Barry Hesketh
31 Posted 04/10/2023 at 19:57:49
31 Posted 04/10/2023 at 19:57:49
Manchester United (2nd) qualified for the European Cup as the 1967â€“68 European Cup winners. Alongside champions Manchester City.
Everton (5th) were ineligible to participate in the Inter-Cities Fairs Cup as Liverpool(3rd) had already qualified. Under the rules of the cup, only one team per city could participate. Chelsea (6th) took their place as the highest-ranked team that hadn't already qualified for a European competition.
West Bromwich Albion (8th) qualified for the European Cup Winners' Cup as the 1967-68 FA Cup winners.
Arsenal (9th) and Tottenham Hotspur (7th) were ineligible to participate in the Inter-Cities Fairs Cup as Chelsea had already qualified. Under the rules of the cup, only one team per city could participate.
Newcastle United (10th) took their place as the highest-ranked team that hadn't already qualified for a European competition.

Going with 1955 then, a woman named Martha Graham in the US died four years after Newcastle last won a major trophy was actually born in 1844.

Paul, that was a good team. David Craig played for Northern Ireland. I think Iam McFaul got a few caps but was understudy to the mighty Pat Jennings. He went to Newcastle from Linfield for £10,000 which was a king's ransom for and Irish league team.
Bobby Moncur looked like my dad and Joe Harvey looked likey granddad. Actually, in those days managers all looked old and wouldn't have been seen dead in a track suit.
Stan Cullis
Tony Waddington
Joe Harvey
Joe Mercer
Bob Stokoe
Bill Nicholson.
Matt Busby
Ah, the good old days, of inside-rights and inside-lefts, right-halves and left-halves and skinny malnourished wingers.

It seems to protect only the chosen few clubs, I dislike this looking at the build-up to an incident rather than the incident in isolation. If somebody gets pushed on the half-way line and the official missed it, and somebody goes on to score a goal, a few moves later, it should be a given as a goal. How far back should they go?
Anyway it's all good preparation for Brighton and their game on Sunday, they might find a few weird decisions being made.
